name: cutandrun-histone-profiling
title: CUT&RUN Histone Modification Profiling
description: High-resolution histone modification mapping using CUT&RUN. Low background, low cell input, and precise chromatin profiling for epigenetic analysis. Samplesheet format: `sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,replicate,antibody,control`
content:
CUT&RUN for Histone Modifications

CUT&RUN (Cleavage Under Targets and Release Using Nuclease) is a superior alternative to ChIP-seq for mapping histone modifications. It provides low background, requires fewer cells, and delivers high-resolution chromatin profiling.

What is CUT&RUN?

The Technique:

  1. Intact Cells/Nuclei: No crosslinking needed (unlike ChIP)
  2. Antibody Binding: Add antibody to target histone mark in permeabilized cells
  3. pA-MNase: Protein A-MNase fusion binds antibody
  4. Activate MNase: Add calcium to cut DNA around antibody target
  5. Release Fragments: Cut DNA fragments diffuse out of nucleus
  6. Sequence: Library prep and sequencing

Why CUT&RUN vs ChIP-seq?

FeatureCUT&RUNChIP-seq
Cell Input10-100K cells1-10M cells
BackgroundVery lowHigher
ResolutionHigherLower
Crosslinking❌ Not required✅ Required
Sonication❌ No✅ Yes
Time1 day3-4 days
Antibody AmountLowHigh
Spike-in Controls✅ Standard⚠️ Rarely used

Advantages of CUT&RUN

  • Low Cell Input: 10-100K cells vs 1-10M for ChIP
  • Low Background: In situ digestion releases only target-bound DNA
  • High Resolution: Precise cutting at nucleosome boundaries
  • No Crosslinking Artifacts: Native chromatin structure preserved
  • Faster: 1 day protocol vs 3-4 days for ChIP
  • Spike-in Normalization: Built-in controls (Drosophila or E. coli chromatin)
  • Less Antibody: Requires much less antibody than ChIP

Histone Marks for CUT&RUN

Active Marks:

  • H3K4me3: Active promoters (excellent with CUT&RUN)
  • H3K4me1: Enhancers
  • H3K27ac: Active enhancers/promoters
  • H3K36me3: Transcribed gene bodies

Repressive Marks:

  • H3K27me3: Polycomb repression (works very well)
  • H3K9me3: Heterochromatin

Note: CUT&RUN works exceptionally well for all histone marks, often better than ChIP-seq due to lower background.

Spike-in Normalization

Why Spike-ins?

  • Normalize for technical variation between samples
  • Account for differences in cell number, antibody efficiency
  • Enable quantitative comparison of histone mark levels

Common Spike-ins:

  • Drosophila chromatin: Add fixed amount to each sample
  • E. coli DNA: Carry-through control

Analysis:

  • Align reads to both target genome and spike-in genome
  • Normalize signal by spike-in read counts
  • Results: Quantitative histone mark levels, not just peaks

Pipeline Analysis

  1. Quality Control: FastQC, fragment size distribution
  2. Alignment: Bowtie2 maps paired-end reads
  3. Spike-in Normalization: Separate alignment to spike-in genome
  4. Duplicate Removal: Mark/remove PCR duplicates
  5. Peak Calling: SEACR (CUT&RUN-specific) or MACS2
  6. Peak Annotation: Assign to genomic features
  7. Differential Analysis: Compare histone mark levels between conditions
  8. Visualization: Normalized BigWig tracks

Peak Callers

SEACR (Sparse Enrichment Analysis for CUT&RUN):

  • Designed specifically for CUT&RUN low-background data
  • Works with or without input control
  • Recommended for CUT&RUN

MACS2/MACS3:

  • Traditional peak caller from ChIP-seq
  • Works well for sharp histone marks (H3K4me3)
  • Use broad peak mode for spreading marks (H3K27me3, H3K9me3)

Scientific Questions

  • Chromatin States: Active vs repressed regions
  • Enhancer Activity: H3K27ac at distal elements
  • Polycomb Targets: H3K27me3 at developmental genes
  • Quantitative Changes: Does drug treatment reduce H3K27me3?
  • Bivalent Chromatin: Co-occurrence of H3K4me3 + H3K27me3
  • Heterochromatin Spreading: H3K9me3 expansion in aging

Applications

  • Cancer: EZH2 inhibitor effects on H3K27me3
  • Stem Cells: Chromatin changes during differentiation
  • Aging: Epigenetic drift (H3K4me3 loss, H3K27me3 changes)
  • Development: Dynamic histone marking during organogenesis
  • Disease Modeling: Aberrant chromatin in Alzheimer's, cancer
  • Drug Discovery: Epigenetic drug MOA (HDAC inhibitors, BET inhibitors)

Input Requirements

CSV samplesheet with columns:

  • group: Sample group name
  • replicate: Replicate number
  • fastq_1: Path to R1 FASTQ
  • fastq_2: Path to R2 FASTQ
  • control: Matching IgG control sample (or use --igg_scale_factor)

Key Outputs

  • Peak Calls: SEACR/MACS2 peaks (BED format)
  • Normalized BigWigs: Spike-in normalized tracks
  • Fragment Size Distribution: QC metric
  • Peak Annotations: Genomic features
  • Differential Peaks: Condition-specific changes
  • Heatmaps: Signal at promoters/enhancers
  • QC Report: MultiQC summary

Perfect for: Histone modifications • Low cell input • High resolution • Quantitative analysis • Spike-in normalization • Drug effects
